Tyler, a couple things off the top of my head that are worth trying
with NE=
AT: 

-You could try a smaller weight_mut_power, like 0.5, for example.  In=

some domains that can encourage more fine tuning.

-The dropoff_age could =
be a lot higher, like 150, or even 500, to give
each species more time befo=
re they get purged for being stuck.

As far as what they need to sense, I w=
ould suggest they need to have
some sense of the location of their center o=
f mass relative to the
ground, and also the velocity of their center of mas=
s relative to the
ground.  Since I think only the vertical dimension matter=
s for this,
you could just tell it the vertical component of both of these.=
 
However, perhaps also the horizontal component can be helpful, if you
cou=
ld in some way express how the horizontal alignment of the center
of mass r=
elative to the body (for example, if your legs are both to
one side of the =
COM, you probably need to shift your weight).

It does seem to me very diff=
icult to balance if you have no idea how
your overall center is positioned.=


I don't think you really need body part positions...angles should be
suff=
icient since evolution can learn the relationship between joint
angles and =
changes in the center of mass.  

A really interesting question is how you =
can encourage walking one
step at a time, as opposed to the two-foot hoppin=
g I saw on your web
page.  It may be necessary to explicitly block that kin=
d of behavior
somehow.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Tyler Streeter <t=
ylerstreeter@y...>
wrote:
> 
> > What kind of comments are you looking for?=
 
> 
> I guess right now I would like to know what ideas
> people have for =
neural net inputs.  First, I tried
> inputting the angles of each joint in =
the body.  That
> way, they have some sense of their body's
> pose/gesture.=
  Lately I have been thinking of the
> following options for neural net inp=
uts:
> 
> * joint angles
> * joint velocities
> * body part positions (glob=
al coordinates or maybe
> offset from the center of mass)
> * overall cente=
r of mass
> * forces on body parts
> 
> They need to have enough informatio=
n to be able to
> perform a complex sequence of actions (e.g. walking). 
> =
Any thought on these ideas for inputs or have other
> ideas?  Do you think =
some are more or less important?
> 
> Thanks.
> 
> Tyler
